headline: The Easier to Vote, Harder to Cheat Act? Anonymous Republicans think we'd fall for that?
author: Laurie Roberts
sentences:
“For purposes of this section, a communication is not impartial or neutral if it is distributed or directed to individuals based in whole or part on such individuals’ race, ethnicity, age, gender, geographic location or residence within the election jurisdiction or actual or presumed political party affiliation or preference.”
In other words, no longer could county elections officials go out and talk to people about the importance of voting or register voters at community events on Native American reservations or in low-income, minority areas.

“What we’re really trying to do here – and I will acknowledge the initiative doesn’t come right out here and say this – what we’re really trying to do is put the counties in a position where 99% of the votes cast in any particular general election are counted by the time the sun comes up on the Wednesday after the election,” Lee Miller, a Republican election attorney and former assistant secretawho is representing the campaign committee, told the Arizona Mirror’s Jeremy Duda.

In 2018, then-Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes made it easier for such people to vote, opening emergency voting centers in Mesa, Scottsdale, Avondale and Tolleson, in addition to the usual emergency voting site at the Maricopa County Recorder’s Office in downtown Phoenix.

Sen. Michelle Ugenti-Rita, R-Scottsdale, offered a similar proposal last year, implying there was a plot afoot by a certain county recorder who she would not name to go only to events where he (or she) would register voters of a certain political persuasion.

The EVHC Act says no government employee “may expend or use public resources to prepare or disseminate any communication related to voter registration or voter processes, procedures or deadlines that is not impartial or neutral.”

Under the EVHC Act, all early ballots – other than military and overseas ballots, which are governed by federal law – would have to be received by 7 p.m. on the Friday before the election to be counted.

In fact, this proposal seems more about allowing a new legal sort of cheating, by limiting participation in Arizona’s elections.
